Title:
Miscanthus sinensis x giganteus harbouring phytopathogenic
for maize cultivable bacteria Pantoea ananatis
Keywords:
Pantoea anantis; endophyte; giant miscanthus, Miscanthus
sinensis x giganteus; phytopathogen, maize
Abstract:
Bacteria inhabiting interior tissues of plants could play
an essential role as factor affecting plant nutritions, plant
development as well as potential biocontrol agents. Giant miscanthus
(Miscanthus sinensis x giganteus Greef et Deu), became an important C4
plant cultivated as a renewable energy source in different regions,
which require low mineral fertilization because according to literature
its tissues are inhabited by nitrogen fixing bacteria. We isolated 20
endophytic bacteria from healthy field-growth steams of giant miscanthus
plants cultivated by seven years on experimental plot in Poland without
fertilization. Selected isolates were tested for the ability of nitrogen
fixation but none of tested strains were not able to grown in semi
liquid Nfb medium and we did not detect the presence of the nitrogenase
reductase gene nifH. Unexpectedly, we found that dominant cultivable
endophytic bacteria, 13 out of 20, based on sequencing 16S rRNA gene
were identified as Pantoea ananatis strains. Moreover, maize seed
inoculations with five selected P.Â ananatis strains revealed its
pathogenicity, deterioration and browning of roots or epicotyl of mize
seedlings. The PCR with specific primers PanITS1 and EC5-Gi confirmed
its phylogenetic position. Selected strains of P.Â ananatis produced IAA
but we did not found ACC gene acdS. Also, selected five strains
inhibited in vivo growth of F.Â culmorum and Ph.Â cactorum as well as 4
and 3 strains strains inhibited growth of F.Â oxysporum and Rh. solani.
The occurrence of endophytic Pantoea ananatis inhabiting interior stems
tissues of giant miscanthus is a first report in literature.
